title: NSW swim sites in good condition: report
text:
More than eight in 10 natural swimming spots in NSW have been deemed suitable for swimming most of the time.

The NSW government's State of the Beaches report for 2018-19 found 86 per cent of the 228 assessed beaches, ocean baths, river areas, lakes and lagoon swimming sites were in "good" or "very good" condition.

This meant they were suitable for swimming most or almost all of the time.

NSW Environment Minister Matt Kean said almost all assessed NSW beaches were found to be clean, the product of dry weather conditions in coastal areas.

Only three beaches were deemed in poor condition - Toowoon Bay on the Central Coast, Malabar Beach in Sydney and Surf Beach on the South Coast.

Terrigal Beach, meanwhile, was upgraded to "good" from "poor".

"Clean beaches are great news for the community and encourage more people to get out and about as we head into the start of the swimming season," Mr Kean said in a statement on Sunday.

But heavy rains had caused issues at NSW lake and lagoon sites, with the number of clean swimming spots falling to just five out of 19.

Mr Kean said lakes and lagoons take longer to recover from stormwater events due to slower flushing of contaminated water.
